, her daughter Eliza, Tingey, David Blair, and a man named Hagan there, but not Walton, and there was a man in possession with a distress-warrant for rent; I went up stairs, and they all sat there, playing at dominoes - we found nothing in that room; I then went up to the next room, which has two beds in it, and there found twenty-three pairs of new shoes and an odd one - we brought them down, and took the prisoners into custody; I asked the broker if the shoes were in his inventory; he did not claim them - I have known Mr. and Mrs. Cook nine or ten years; they did not deal in shoes - they sold coals about in a cart: Manning claimed the shoes before the Magistrate - Walton was then in custody.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Tingey was not in the room you found the shoes in? A. No - the man in possession was not playing with them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Mr. Cook was not in the house then, but you cannot tell how long the shoes had been there? A. No; I believe Cook is now in Newgate, on another charge - I went to the house about twenty minutes after Carter gave me the information.

JOHN FOWLER
. I am a constable. I went to Cook's house with Ingram, and found twenty-three pairs of shoes and an odd one, strewed on the bed - Tingey and Mrs. Cook were there; I had taken Mr. Cook to Newgate on another charge that morning, having apprehended him on the Tuesday - he could not have been present when the shoes were brought there; Hagan and another were discharged before the Magistrate - I saw Camp find a piece of paper in Cook's house.

JOSEPH FORSTER
. I am a constable. I was with Fowler and the others; we got to Cook's house at near ten o'clock- Mr. Cook had been sent to Newgate that morning - I saw Tingey, Mrs. Cook, and several others playing at dominoes - Fowler and lugram went up stairs; I stood at the door, to prevent the prisoners leaving the room - I found a large clasp knife in Tingey's pocket: there had been a rope round the hamper, which was cut; I saw part of the cord, which was found near where the shoes were lost.

BENJAMIN AVLIN
. I am a barge-owner. I know all the prisoners - I went to Cook's house on the 25th of January, with the constables; I stood at the door while they went up - they called me up, and I saw the shoes in the bed room.

JOHN CAMP
. I am a constable of Edmonton. On Wednesday evening Game informed me of his loss - I apprehended Walton on Sunday morning, about four o'clock, in bed, at his mother's, at Edmonton; I told him it was for stealing shoes from Game's cart - he denied the charge, and said it was the first he had heard of it: on the day after the robbery I went to Cook's house, to search for more property, and in the room where the shoes were found I found this paper laying by the side of the bed - it has been apparently burnt with a candle and dropped down.

WILLIAM MANNING
. I know these shoes - they have all our stamp on them; one pair was made by our apprentice - I know his work; that pair was sent in the hamper; this paper is part of the invoice which was sent with them.

WILLIAM BOYSON
. I am a watchman. On Wednesday evening, the 25th of January, about half-past seven o'clock, Game's cart passed me in Claremont-street, in the upper part of Edmonton, about a quarter of a mile on this side the Angel, and about twenty minutes to eight Walton and Tingey passed me; they were going afterthe cart, walking very fast in the same direction - I saw Walton again about ten minutes past nine o'clock, coming in the same direction as before; I did not see that he had any thing with him - he was against Mr. Brooks', going down the lane towards his own home; I saw Camp, and told him.
Walton's Defence. I was not in the house that night.
Tingey's Defence. I went to Cook's, but took nothing with me.
Cook's Defence. When I go out on business I cannot say who goes into my place - there are no locks on any of the doors.
JOSEPH FORSTER. There is no lock on the street door- I did not observe the bed-room doors.

WALTON -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

TINGEY -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

COOK -
GUILTY . Aged 51.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

732.
BRIDGET KELLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on 15th of February , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 9d., and 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Read Hayes
.

MARY HAYES
. I am the wife of
Read Hayes
, a shoemaker , of Royal Hospital-row, Chelsea
. The prisoner had ordered a pair of shoes, and was to have come for them on the Saturday before this, but did not - I went out about ten o'clock in the morning, on the 15th of February, and left my mother in care of the shop; I put these boots in the window five minutes before I went out - I returned about twelve o'clock, and missed them about two; the shoes have not been found, but the boots I found in pawn - the prisoner is friendless, and has no parents; I never heard a charge against her.

SARAH TABOR
. I am Hayes' mother. I was in care of the shop - the prisoner came, and asked if her shoes were done - I said my daughter was out, and I did not know; she turned to the window, took a pair of shoes down, and tried on - she said it was a very good fit, and she would come and fetch them in a minute; she was not in the shop after that - I sat there with the baby, and never left; about two o'clock my daughter discovered the loss - nobody but the prisoner had been to the shop; I saw her handling the boots, but she put them down again.

CHARLES BOND
. I am apprentice to Mr. Perkins, a pawnbroker, On the 15th of February the prisoner pawned a pair of child's boots for 6d. - I am certain of her.

HENRY WILLIAMS
. I am a Policeman. I took her into custody - she did not deny the charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 17. -
Judgment Respited
.

733.
HENRY MESSENGER, alias MESSENBERG
, and
THOMAS COOK
were indicted for
breaking and entering a building, within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
John O'Brien
, on the 23rd of January , and stealing 10 fowls, value 10s.; 1 stirrup, value 1s., and 1 pint pot, value 1d., the goods of
John O'Brien
; 2 shirts, value 5s.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 coat, value 1s. 6d., and 1 pair of stockings, value 6d., the goods of
Henry Robinson
.

JOHN O'BRIEN
. I am a mariner , and rent a house in Edmonton parish
. On the 23rd of January my servant reported that my hen-house was broken open; I was not at home that night - the hen-house is in my yard, and does not communicate with the house; Robinson sleeps in the same room with my father.

HENRY ROBINSON
. I am servant to Mr. O'Brien, On the 23rd of January I went to bed about ten o'clock at night - I left two shirts, a handkerchief, a coat, and stockings in a bundle in the stable, which is enclosed in the yard; the door was shut, and the hen-house door was locked - I left all safe about half-past nine o'clock; about half-past six in the morning I found all the things laying about, and missed my clothes - I found an iron crow in the stable; it did not belong to us - the hen-house door was shut, but the lock had been shoved back, and fourteen fowls taken out of twenty; I saw the prisoners in custody the next day, with five fowls - I knew there were two particular French ones among them, which I can safely swear to.

JOSEPH FORSTER
. I am a constable. On the 24th of January I received information about five o'clock, and went to Cook's house, with Fowler and Aylin - I have seen Messenger there a good deal, but do not think he lived there regularly; I found Cook, his son, and Messenger there - as soon as we could obtain a light, Fowler and I searched the house, leaving Aylin at the streetdoor, and while we were searching, Aylin brought up a bag, in which was a large doe-rabbit and a fowl - Ingram found a rabbit and three or four fowls; we immediately took the prisoners into custody - Robinson claimed the fowls before the Magistrate.
Cross-examined. Q. Messenger occasionally lived at Cook's? A. I do not say he lived there - I never saw him in bed there; I found him there dressed.

BENJAMIN AYLIN
. I went to Cook's house, and was stationed at the door - while the officers were searching something came out of the window, and fell on my head -I sent for a light, and found a bag at my heels, with a rabbit and two fowls in it; they were warm and just killed - that must have been what came on my head; I went upstairs, and told them what I had found - a rabbit and three fowls were thrown out of a window into the yard; I could not say from which window they came, but only one was open when the light came; Robinson claimed the fowls.

Cross-examined. Q. How many houses are there together? A. There are three in the yard; there are two rooms and a cellar in Cook's house - there is no room on the ground floor; I know Messenger occasionally slept there; Cook's son is about twenty-one years old - he was sitting at the fire with them; the bag must have come from Cook's window.

JOHN FOWLER
. I am a constable. I went to the house - we searched the room, and found nothing but the back part and the gut of a fowl in a part of water - Aylin called out that something was thrown out of window, and we immediately apprehended the prisoners - Robinson identified the fowls before the Magistrate; Cook's son was discharged.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he dressed? A. Yes, but his shoes were not laced.

JOHN INGRAM. I live near the yard, in which Cook's house is. On the 24th of January, between six and seven o'clock in the morning, Fowler called me; I went to Cook's house with a candle - it went out; I went for another, and in the yard, under Cook's window, I found a rabbit and three fowls, dead, but quite warm - they were not in a bag; Robinson claimed them.

HENRY ROBINSON
. I am quite sure the fowls were my master's - here are the wings and feet, which I swear to.
Cross-examined. Q. Is not that quite a common plumage? A. Perhaps it may be.
Cook's Defence. I was in bed at half-past ten o'clock, and did not get up till six.

Messenger's Defence. Fowler had stopped me the day day before, when I was coming up here to a young woman who was in trouble - I slept in town that night; I got up next morning, went to Tottenham, and called at Cook's, about six o'clock - Fowler saw me go in, and knew I had nothing.

JOHN FOWLER
. I did not see him till he was found in the house; I was in bed when I received the information.

COOK -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

MESSENGER -
GUILTY . Aged 49.
Transported for Life .

734.
CHARLES MILLS
was
indicted for embezzlement .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN HITCHCOCK
, I am servant to Mrs. Constable, of Sloane-street
, I have some table-cloths, which a young man brought to mistress's house about two months ago - I do not know who it was; I did not have a receipt.

JAMES CORDNER
. I am in the employ of
Messrs.
Sewell and Cross
, at their shop at Knightsbridge; the prisoner was in their service. On Thursday, the 15th of December, I sent him to Mrs. Constable's with some table-cloths, and as soon as he returned I asked him if they would suit - he said the lady could not give a deoided answer till the following morning; he afterwards told me the cloths were returned, that the lady objected to the price, and would not keep them; the cloths produced are the two which I sent him with to Mrs. Constable's - they came to 27s.; he should have accounted to Mr. Challacomb if he was paid for them.

NICHOLAS CHALLACOMB
. I manage the branch concern for Messrs.
George Drake Sewell
and another, at Knights-bridge. If shopmen are sent out with goods and receive money for them they ought to account to me, and to nobody else - the prisoner never accounted to me for the cash for these cloths; he left, without notice, on the 26th of December.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you happen to know he is the son of a highly respectable linen-draper in Bond-street? A. No - he said his health had been bad before I engaged him.

JOSEPH MILLER
. I am a fishmonger, and live in Piccadilly. I received goods amounting to 15l. 9s. 7d. from Messrs. Sewell and Cross on the 18th of December; I paid the prisoner for them; here is the receipt which I saw him write - (read.)

NICHOLAS CHALLACOMB. The prisoner never accounted to me for this sum, which it was his duty to do that very day - Mrs. Constable gave me this receipt, which he gave for the table-cloths; I know it to be his writing - (read.)
Prisoner. I wrote a letter to the prosecutors.

HENRY MILLS
. The prisoner is my son. I was formerly in business in Bond-street and in Coventry-street for twenty-four years - my son has been in a bad state of health some years, from a violent fever; we consider him of very weak intellect - he left several situations on account of his intellects.
COURT. Q. Do you mean to say he did not know right from wrong? A. He has gone on in that sort of way I should say he is not competent to know right from wrong.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is he competent to write a receipt? A. Yes; writing is the only thing he does tolerably well.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Year .

735.
JAMES CLEMENTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of January , 720 strawberry pottle-baskets, value 20s. , the goods of
James Norris
, the younger.

GEORGE WARE
. I am watchman to
James Norris
, a market-gardener , at Isleworth
. On the 21st of January, about two o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner - he came to the door of the shed where these baskets were, and tried to lift the latch, but found it fast; he then went to a window, wrenched one of the shutters open, then wrenched two iron bars, which were across the window, and got in - I was concealed inside the place; he began to throw the baskets out - he threw sixty dozens out, and was shutting the window up that they should not be missed - I went round, and secured him; he must have opened the gate or climbed over to get to the premises.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

736.
HENRY TAYLOR
and
JOHN OAKHAM
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February , 2 tons of stones, value 24s. , the goods of
William Newman
.

SECOND COUNT, stating them to belong to
John Leach Painton
, the principal clerk for the time being of the Commissioners of the turnpike roads in the neighbourhood of the metropolis, north of the river Thames .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BUNCE
. I am a labourer, and live at Fulham; I was in the employ of Mr. Sparks to draw materials on the roads. On Friday, the 9th of February, I was unloading a load of stones at Badcock's wharf, Chelsea
- Taylor was in Sparks' (the contractor) service, and drove the horse - about a quarter-past six o'clock the last cart was loaded from the barge, with about two tons; Taylor drove it away.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had he driven much that day? A. Five loads - I did not notice whether his horses were tired.
Cross-examined. Q. Might not somebody have persuaded Taylor to shoot stones there? A. That is impossible for me to tell; he had only four hundred yards to come into our road.

SAMUEL HARRISON. I am a nurseryman, and live in Alexander-square, Brompton. On Thursday, the 8th of February, I saw the prisoners at my door; Oakham asked if I wanted to buy gravel; I said I wanted a few loads, very course, to form the foundation of a road in front of my house; they said they could sell me some; I agreed for four loads at 4s. a load; they said they got it from the bed of the river, as it fell over from the barges; they brought two loads next morning, which I thought was chiefly stone - I did not see it shot; four cart loads were deposited there, two on Friday, and on Saturday another, that was of a different description; I said it was not what I was in the habit of having, and I should have no more.

CHARLES GALLATLY
. I am servant to Mr. Bonnet, of Onslow-cottage, Fulham. On the 9th of February, about five o'clock in the morning, I saw Oakham nearly opposite Mr. Harrison's, shooting a load of stone, and while I was talking to him, my master came by - I told master a load of it would do for the road in front of his house; he asked Oakham the price - he said five shillings, and master said"Bring me a load to-morrow," and on Saturday morning at seven o'clock, when I went to work, there were two loads shot, one for master and one for Harrison; Oakham came, and master paid him.

JOHN LEE
. I live in Godfrey-street. On Friday night, the 10th of February, I heard a cart-load of stones shot -I threw up my window, and saw Taylor shooting a load of stones; I went down, and said, "Young man, what does this mean? you are shooting on private property;" he said' "I am late, and have to fetch my hay and corn; I will take it away in the morning;" on the following morning, about a quarter to seven o'clock, I saw Oakham filling the same stones into a cart - he said, "Halloo, Lee!" I said, "I don't know what you are up to."
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you know Taylor before? A. I have seen him several times - it was moon-light.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Did you know Oakham before? A. Yes - I did not notice the cart.
COURT. Q. How far is Godfrey-street from Badcock's wharf? A. About half a mile.

CHARLES HUGHES
. I am a constable of Chelsea. The stones that fall from the barges are taken up by the men -I am employed to prevent it. On Friday evening, the 10th of February, I saw Taylor draw a load of stones from the wharf, and next morning I traced the wheel of a cart out of Jubilee-place, where it should be shot down, to Godfrey-street, and some stones remained there, which I would swear were the same as were being unloaded - the cart had no business in Godfrey-street - I traced the wheel out of Godfrey-street into the road again to the stable - I compared the stones in Godfrey-street with those in Alexander-square; they are peculiar from all other stones; I went to Oakham's lodgings, and told him I wanted him for stealing stones, which belonged to the trust; he said he had picked up two loads of shoreings, and sold them to Harrison, and shot two loads in Godfrey-street - I took him to Newman; he then said,"I hope you will look over it this time" - I took Taylor, and told him it was for the two loads of stone in Godfrey-street; he said, "D-n it, I meant to have taken them up again;" I said he had no business to shoot them there - he said he wanted to go home for his corn.

TAYLOR -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Two Months .

OAKHAM -
NOT GUILTY .

737.
WILLIAM PUZEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 5 pieces of veneer, value 30s., the goods of
Uriah Macey
and another .

SAMUEL TOPLIS
. I am a cabinet-maker, and have been a bankrupt - Uriah Macey and another are our assignee s; we had given the prisoner leave to use our saw-pit - he was sawing there with another man; we had a quantity of veneers in a room opposite the saw-pit; it was never locked. On the 31st of January I was standing in the kitchen, opposite the gateway, and saw him taking some veneers under his arm up the gateway - I ran after him, and caught him about one hundred yards from the premises, with five pieces of veneer.

Prisoner. I was employed by Smith, who told me to take them to his house - I told Mr. Toplis so; he said,"They don't belong to him" - Smith is now in prison. Witness. He gave this account when I stopped him; I went back to Smith, who said he had given him no such directions.

JOHN MOULD
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner in charge - he said he was employed by Smith; I apprehended Smith on the 11th of February, in the Borough, and he is now in custody.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I took it by Smith's order.
MR. TOPLIS. The veneers were in a room nearly opposite the saw-pit, but further down the yard; I did not see him come out of the room - he and Smith were working together in the pit.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Confined Six Months .

738.
JAMES PULLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 1 iron weight, value 18d. , the goods of
John Newton
.

JOHN NEWTON
. I am a baker , and live in Philip-street, Kingsland-road
. On the 14th of February, when I came home, about nine o'clock at night, I missed this weight from the flour-machine, at the back of the shop; I do not know the prisoner; I found it at Woolf's marine-store shop at Hoxton.

THOMAS BULLOCK
. I am fourteen years old, and live in Philip-street. I was in Newton's shop about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, and saw the prisoner come into the shop and run out again - I did not see him take any thing; there was a gas-light on the counter - I amsure of him: I saw him in custody that night - Mrs. Newton missed the weight in a quarter of an hour.

DAVID SAWYER
. I am a gardener. I saw the prisoner with the weight in Cross-street, about a stone's throw from the iron shop, and going towards it; I asked where he got it - he said he took it out of a shop.

SARAH WOOLF
. My husband is a plate-worker - we live at No. 116. Hoxton-town, and deal in marine-stores; I bought this weight of a youth, for 6d - I cannot swear to him.

JAMES CLAY
. I apprehended the prisoner at his father's; he escaped into another house, and I found him concealed under a bed.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

739.
THOMAS SPEAK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of February , 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Robert Cox
, his master .

ROBERT COX
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Tothill-street, Westminster
; the prisoner assisted in my shop on Saturdays. On the 11th of February, about ten o'clock, Blackford came and bought a rasher of bacon, which came to 4d. - I was close by the parlour door; he put a shilling on the counter - the prisoner gave him two penny-pieces, and at the same time put his hand in the till, took out some silver, and put into Blackford's hand - Blackford went off with it, without stopping to see if it was right; my son stopped him, and we found two shillings, two sixpences, and two pence in his hand; I took it from him, and both were taken into custody - I am sure I saw the prisoner deliver that money into his hand.

Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Where were you standing? A. Inside the parlour door; there is a glass partition - there are six or seven gas-lights in the shop; Blackford had lived with a cheesemonger in the neighbourhood - he only put a shilling on the counter, and the prisoner rang it; I was watching, having had information that Blackford had received money twice before - he and the prisoner both live near Spitalfields.

CHARLES COX
. I am the prosecutor's son. I saw Blackford come in the afternoon, and buy a piece of cheese, which came to 1s. 6d. - he put down half a crown; I thought the change given was wrong, as I heard silver sound in his hand - he came again about ten o'clock, and bought some bacon; I watched, and he had the right change that time - he came again in a quarter of an hour; I was then in the parlour, and told my father my suspicion - he had a rasher of bacon; I saw him put down a shilling - the prisoner put down some copper: his hand was then in the till for some time - I saw him take something out, and put into Blackford's hand; I went out, caught hold of Blackford's hand, and my father opened it; there were two shillings, two sixpences, and two pence - he said he had given the prisoner half a crown; but at the watch-house he said he had two shillings in his hand when he came into the shop.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see him come in the third time? A. No; I am sure it was a shilling he gave the prisoner, and he could not have other money in his hand, for I saw it open - I am certain the money came out of my father's till.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I know the prisoner and Blackford were acquainted.

JOSEPH BROWN
. I received the prisoner in charge with Blackford, who said he had two shillings in his hand, and afterwards said he had given the prisoner half a crown.
Prisoner's Defence. The man gave me half a crown -I did not know him before.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months .
First London Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

740.
ABRAHAM BAMBRIDGE
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .

WILLIAM BROWNING
. I live with Messrs. Jenkins and Son, Queen-street, Cheapside
, brass-founders. The prisoner came to the shop, and produced this order for two rings of wire, signed T. Giles, who is a customer of ours; he said he came from Giles for two rings of wire; I never saw him before - I had my doubts about it, but called master down, and by his direction gave him the wire -(order read.)

GEORGE HANDS
. I manage Messrs. Jenkins' business . The porter called me down, and produced this order; the wire was delivered to the prisoner - I never saw him before.

THOMAS GILES
. This order was not written by me, nor by my authority.

JOHN MARSHALL
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house on the 1st of February.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had met a man in Chiswell-street, who had given him 6d. to fetch the wire - he received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

741.
WILLIAM HARRIS
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .

GEORGE WILLIAM ACTON
. I keep an oil-shop in Farringdon-street
. On the 2nd of February the prisoner came and asked for three brushes to do some work for Devey and Son, of Shoe-lane, who are customers of ours; and crediting what he said, I gave him three - I did not know him before.

WILLIAM DEVEY
. I am in partnership with
William Rogers Devey
, brass-founder, Shoe-lane. I did not authorise the prisoner to get brushes on our account; he had been in our service, and was discharged at Guildhall on the 4th of August.
GUILTY .

742.
WILLIAM HARRIS
was again
indicted for a like offence .

THOMAS KELSEY
. I am servant to
Mr. Butler
. On the 4th of August the prisoner, who was quite a stranger, came and produced an order for six panes of glass, fifteen inches by thirteen, for Devey and Son; I let him have them, believing the order came from them - (order read.)

WILLIAM ROGERS DEVEY
. This order was not written by me or my father.
WILLIAM DEVEY. It is not written by me, nor by my authority.

GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

743.
WILLIAM PITHOUSE
was
indicted for wilful and corrupt perjury .
The particulars of this case are of too indelicate a nature for publication.

GUILTY. - Aged 18. -
Judgment Respited
.
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

744.
JOHN AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of February , I shoulder of mutton, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Matthews
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months .

745.
JOHN BRINKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of January , 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 2 shifts, unmade, value 5s.; 1 petticoat, value 18d.; 1 gown, value 1s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 18d., the goods of
Thomas Poole
; and that he had been before convicted of felony ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

746.
JOHN ELLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 hat, value 6s. , the goods of
Charles Dyer
: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

747.
EDMUND HILLYER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of January , 1 yard of cloth, value 7s. , the goods of
Thomas Wallis
.

GEORGE POWELL
. I am a Policeman. On the evening of the 16th of January I saw the prisoner at Mr. Wallis' door in Holborn - I saw him pull the cloths, and a piece dropped; he picked it up, and ran away - I secured him with it in his hand, and in bringing him back he dropped this pair of scissors.

THOMAS WALLIS
. I keep a woolen-draper's shop , in High Holborn
. The officer brought the prisoner and this cloth to me - it was hanging at the side of the door.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

748.
GEORGE GILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of December , 2 tea-boards, value 2s.; 2 pokers, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shovel, value 1s.; 1 pair of tongs, value 1s.; 1 looking-glass, value 2s.; 6 pictures, value 2s.; 2 dishes, value 1s.; 1 tea-pot, value 6d.; 3 glasses, value 9d., and 1 work-box, value 6d. , the goods of
Charlotte Gaffney
.

CHARLOTTE GAFFNEY
. I lived on Christmas-eve in Caroline-court, Whitechapel
; I had some friends that night, and the prisoner came to see a young man and woman, who lived in the house. On the 26th of December I left my house at eight o'clock in the evening; my property was then safe - a young woman lived in the house at that time - I returned between eleven and twelve, the young woman was at home; I missed my things.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had the prisoner been often at your house? A. No, the first time was on Christmas-eve - I do not know that he was there after that - he never slept with me - I never knew him to sleep in the house - I did not know that he was in the robbery till I found some of my things; Mr. Duncot used to come backwards and forwards, from knowing Mr. Gill; Duncot was there for a week once, but I did not know him at the time these things were taken; he slept in the same room that I did - I have seen the prisoner since the robbery; he lived at a public-house near where I lived - it is hard for me to tell how often I have been in that public-house with him - Duncot has absconded; I did not know that Gill was in the robbery till Duncot told me so; he never was in my place till Christmas-eve.

Q. Do you mean to swear he never, to your knowledge, slept in your house? A. I never saw him about; he might come to Duncot one night, but I knew nothing about it; he never slept with Duncot to my knowledge; I slept in my own bed - I do not know that Gill and Duncot slept in the same bed.
COURT. Q. Did Gill pass the night in the same room with you and Duncot? A. No; I do not recollect Gill being there on any night.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Upon your oath, did not Gill sleep one night in the same bed with you and Duncot? A I never slept with Gill; I do not recollect his sleeping in the same bed with me and Duncot - I have three beds, one on the other; I have slept on them for nine years - Duncot and I lived together, as man and wife, while he was there; I do not recollect whether I was in the same bed with Gill and Duncot - it is a good bit ago; to my knowledge I never was.

HENRY TONGMAN
. On the 26th of December, the prisoner, Duncot, and three other young men brought a tea-board, a poker, a shovel, and a pair of tongs to my house between eight and nine o'clock in the evening - I could identify the other three, but I do not know their names - Duncot told me that he and his wife were in great distress, and asked if I would buy two or three things of him; he asked 3s. for them, which I gave him; the prisoner did not speak at all.

Cross-examined. Q. Duncot in gone off? A. Yes, Sir; I did not know that he was living with the prosecutrix; I know Gill by his working nearly opposite where I did; he bore an honest character - I suppose they came to me to buy them, because I was lately married.

HENRY THOMAS DALLY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner in the Cannon public-house, Cannon-street-road. he asked me if I wanted him for striking this young woman; I said No, for something done before that; he said he was not in it, that it was Duncot.
Cross-examined. Q. How came you to go to Tongman's house? A. I had been at his house before, with Mrs. Gaffney, and he told me Gill was one of the party; I cannot find Duncot.
NOT GUILTY .

749.
THOMAS LODGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February
, 1 purse, value 6d.; 6 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 1 1/2d, the property of
William Robert Cheeseman
, from the person of
Mary Cheeseman
.

JOHN STANDFAST PICKFORD
. I live in Cross-street, Britannia-street, City-road. On the 4th of February I was in Collingwood-street
, at near nine o'clock in the evening, there was a show; I heard a female scream Stop thief! I saw the prisoner draw his hand from Mrs. Cheeseman's side, make a stride, and run off; he was stopped by a neighbour, and given into my hands.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you sure you are not mistaken in his person? A. Yes, there was a crowd near him, but he was out of the crowd.

MARY CHEESEMAN
. I am the wife of
William Robert Cheeseman
; he is a printer's warehouseman ; we live in Collingwood-street. On the 4th of February I was standing with my child in my arms, looking at the show; I felt the prisoner brush by my side - I turned to look at him, and put my hand outside my clothes and felt my money; I put my hand in my pocket to be more certain, and felt my purse and money - I pulled my gown over it; I then saw the prisoner by my side again - my child being heavy, I put my right hand to its back; I then felt the prisoner touch me again, and missed my money - I turned and looked at him; he walked one or two steps - I caught hold of him; he broke from me, and I cried Stop thief! three or four times; he got a few yards, and was stopped -I had 6s. 9 1/2d. in my purse.
Cross-examined. Q. Has the purse been found? A. No; there was no person on my right hand but the prisoner; there were a good many on my left.

THOMAS BARKER
. I live in Britannia-street. I was at my window - I went down; the prisoner was brought back, and I took charge of him - I found on him, one crown, one half-crown, some shillings and sixpences, and half pence; in all 14s., but no purse.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

750.
THOMAS LODGE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February
, 1 crown, 2 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Henry Jennings
, from the person of
Diana Jennings
.

THOMAS BARKER
. I am a City officer. I heard the alarm on the 4th of February, and took the prisoner about nine o'clock in the evening; I found 14s. on him, and amongst it a crown-piece.

DIANA JENNINGS
. I am the wife of Henry Jennings. On the 4th of February I was near my own door, in Britannia-street
, with my child in my arms; I heard the alarm, and felt in my pocket; I missed a crown-piece, two shillings, and two sixpences; I saw the crown-piece found on the prisoner, and I know it was mine, by some spots of wax on it; my husband is a shoemaker - I had it when I was at my own door.

ELIZA FRANCES JENNINGS
. I was standing by my mother, looking at the exhibition; I found the prisoner standing looking over my shoulder, close to my mother.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years more .

751.
HENRY LEE
and
GEORGE LEWIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of February , 1 shoulder of mutton, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Mendey
.

CHARLES WILLIAM SNOOK
. I live in Garden-row, Brick-lane. On the 2nd of February I was standing at the corner of Wellington-street - I saw the prisoners playing; I afterwards saw Lewis lift Lee up, and he took a shoulder of mutton from Mr. Mendey's shop - I saw Lee in custody, but Lewis ran away; I am certain of them.

THOMAS MENDEY
. I live in Brick-lane , and am a butcher ; I was in my shop - I saw Lee on the back of another boy , and while I was serving a customer a little girl told Snook that a boy had run away with some meat.

JAMES TAYLOR
. I am an officer. I took Lewis in Smithfield - I believe the prisoners were in great distress.

DANIEL CHAPMAN
. I am an officer. I received charge of Lee.

LEE -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

LEWIS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

752.
WILLIAM LOWE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of January , 8 handkerchiefs, value 10s., the goods of
Peter Pige
; and that he had before been convicted of felony .

THOMAS STERN
. I am shopman to Peter Pige, a pawnbroker , of Church-street, Bethnal-green
. On the morning of the 21st of January, I saw the prisoner close to the window - I afterwards saw him running; I went out, stopped him, and took him back to the shop, and found on him these eight silk handkerchiefs, which are my master's.
PETER PIGE. I had seen these handkerchiefs safe about ten minutes before.

Prisoner. Q. Where had they been hanging? A. Over the iron bar outside the window - they were tied by a string; a little girl told me you snatched them off - I pursued, and saw you trying to tuck them under your jacket, as you were running.

Prisoner's Defence. The handkerchiefs were laying under the shop-window; she kicked them with her foot - my wife died three days after I was put in prison, and left four children; I was discharged from the chilvers brig in September.

EDWARD DARKIN
. I am an officer. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office - he had one month imprisonment in the House of Correction; I know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

753.
HENRY MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of February , 3 locks, value 4s.; 8 screws, value 2d., and 8 brass handles, value 2s., the goods of
David Browne
, and fixed to a building of his .

SECOND COUNT, stating them to belong to
Thomas Copeman
.

JOHN MATTHEWS
. I live in Selby-street, Waterloo-town
. On the 6th of February I was in my front room; I saw the prisoner facing my house, opposite the door of an empty house - he went in there, and was there twenty minutes; he went up stairs, came down, took the street door in his hand, and uncrewed the lock - I went out and tried my key to the door; it would not open it - I thought he had gone out, but he had not; he opened the door - I said, "You are a prety rascal, are you not?" I saw some locks in his pocket, and I sent for Humphreys.

EPHRAIM HUMPHREYS
. I live in Agnes-street, Waterloo-town, and am a carpenter. I went to No. 21, Selby-street on the 6th of February - I found the prisoner in custody; I took him to the station - I saw him searched, and three locks, four keys, four handles, two screw-drivers, and a brad-awl found on him.

THOMAS COPEMAN
. I live at No. 24, Selby-street, and am a shoemaker . I have the care of No. 21, which is opposite Mr. Matthews' - I saw the locks and keys all safe three days before; I missed these articles; they all fit the doors exactly.

JOHN DANIEL PASQUE
. I live in Buttress-street. I saw the prisoner about the premises on the Sunday before.

DAVID DICKINSON
. I am clerk to Mr. Temple. The house is the property of Mr. David Browne; he lives in the country - Mr. Copeman has the care of that and several others.

HENRY HUDDY
. I am a Policeman. I searched the prisoner, and found three locks, four keys, four handles, two screw-drivers, and one brad-awl - I went and fitted the locks to the house.
Prisoner. I did not open the house; I picked them up in the house.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Transported for Seven Years .

754.
JOHN MARTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of January , 1 lamp, value 12s. , the goods of
George Ingram
.

ROBERT DIXON
. I am journeyman to Mr. Ingram, a coach-maker , of Great Queen-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields
. He lost from his warehouse, a pair of lamps, on Monday, the 23rd of January - they had just been japanned.

THOMAS DELANY
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty on the 23rd of January, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, in Short's-gardens, Drury-lane; I saw the prisoner running up Short's-gardens, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I stopped him, and found nothing on him; I asked how he came to run if he was not guilty - he said he thought the officer saw him take the lamp.

CHARLES WILKINS
. I am a Policeman. On the afternoon of the 23rd of January, between three and four o'clock, I was in Drury-lane, and saw the prisoner at the corner of Queen-street, with this lamp - he was carrying it under his arm; he ran away, and I followed him - he threw it down in Short's-gardens; I never lost sight of him; the japan was wet on the lamp.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had met a man named Wilson, in Queen-street, who gave him the lamp as a pattern to make one for him.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Three Months .

755.
JOSEPH PRIESTLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of February , 24 pennies and 36 halfpennies, the monies of
Sarah Gurney
, his mistress .

SARAH GURNEY
. I am a widow , and keep the Old King's Arms, Gray's Inn-lane . On the 27th of January I sent the prisoner, with 3s. 6d. in copper, to Mr. Bennett; he returned, and I asked if he had paid the money - he said Yes; I afterwards saw Bennett, and in consequence of what he said I spoke to the prisoner - he said he had not paid the money, that he had got into bad company and lost it - he ran away directly; he had been eleven months with me, and had been a good boy for about nine months.

HENRY BENNETT
. I live in Upper North-place, Gray's Inn-lane
. On the 27th of January I served the prisoner with some ribbon, on the account of Mrs. Gurney, which came to 3s. 6d. - he never came to pay me for it.

JOHN BURTON
. I was an officer. I took the prisoner on the 3rd of February; he begged I would not take him, and in going along he said his clothes and handkerchief, which were in his box, would settle it.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

756.
ISABELLA DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of January , 1 cap, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
Joseph Allen
.

ANN LOUISA ALLEN
. I am the wife of Joseph Allen. I keep a milliner's shop in Norton-falgate
; the prisoner came there on the 17th of January, alone - I was standing in the back parlour; I saw her take up a cap out of the window, and a blue handkerchief - I went into the shop, and when I saw her I knew her very well, and thought it was of no use to speak to her then - she dropped the cap, as I suppose, between herself and the counter; I went into the parlour again, and told my girls to watch - they gave me information; I went out when they said, "Now, Ma'am;" I found her with a cap, which she had taken - he came to buy nothing, but in the same manner as she had come before - she desired me to put a cap by for her, and not to mix it.

CAROLINE LITTLE
. I was in the parlour - Mrs. Allen came into the parlour and told us to watch, and I saw the prisoner drop the cap; then she stopped down and put something into her bosom.

HENRY DEPIES
. I am an officer, and have the cap, which I saw Mrs. Allen take from her; I heard her say,"You have robbed me, and I know you have the property;" she took this cap from her bosom - she was searched in my presence, and another new cap was found on her, and half a yard of lace; she had a sovereign and three duplicates.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it about a fortnight before, of a young lady who was in her shop, for half a crown; I am a mantua-maker - there are plenty of caps like that.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .

757.
WILLIAM BERRY
,
JOHN BERRY
,
WILLIAM TAYLOR
, and
BENJAMIN CATLING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of February , 16 bushels of wheat, value 5l. , the goods of
William Boards
.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM BOARDS
. I live at Edmonton
, and am a farmer .
John Wheeler
fastened my barn on the night of the 6th of February, and next morning he told me it was broken open - I examined, and found part of the roof had been untiled, sufficient for two to have got in; I missed some wheat from the bulk - I thought about two quarters; I found a hat in the barn, which I believe is here - I gave notice to Camp, the officer, and went with him to Taylor's, at a place called Journeyman's-green, on the following day - I think Wheeler went with me; Catling lives next door to Taylor - I found at Taylor's a bed-tick filled with wheat in the chaff, and the bed clothes on it - the bed appeared made; I think there were about six bushels in the tick, and I found about five pecks in a sack in the house -I have compared the wheat I found there with that in my barn, and I believe it to be part of the same wheat; I found at Catling's about five pecks of wheat, from which the chaff had been blown, and some chaff was buried by the side of the house.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Do you pretend to distinguish your wheat from other wheat? A. As far as possible, I think I can - there is much difference in thequality, weight, and colour of it; it was in the chaff, in which state it is not sold - it was very good, and cleaner than it is in general; that I found at Catling's was not in the chaff, but it was not then in a marketable state - it was in such a state as a poor person might have it for his own use; Catling was in my service about three years ago - I do not know that we had any difference; I do not recollect having a fowl injured or killed, or talking of instituting a prosecution against any body, and applying to Catling to give evidence - he made a false charge against me, but I am ready to meet it in any way.

JOHN WHEELER
. I am thresher to Mr. Boards. I made his barn fast on the night of the 6th of February, and the next morning I found the roof broken - I think about two quarters of wheat were missing; I saw the wheat which was found at the prisoner's; in my judgment it was the same as the bulk - that found at Catling's had been partly cleaned, but not entirely.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you not said before that you could not say that it was the same wheat? A. No, Sir, I never said so to any one - I said I could not positively swear to it, but I believe it was the wheat.

DANIEL BARNES
. I am a watchman of Edmonton. On the night of the 6th of February, at twenty minutes past ten o'clock I saw the four prisoners together, at the William the Fourth beer-shop, which is about three quarters of a mile from Mr. Boards'; (they had gone through the town about nine) - as I was proceeding on my beat they overtook me in a lane which leads to Mr. Boards' barn, but about half a mile from it - this was about halfpast ten o'clock; Taylor and Catling collared me, and said they did not care for such a d-d watchman as me; I had not done any thing to them.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they in the road to Catling's house? A. Yes, they could go that way; I should not have noticed them if they had not noticed me.

JAMES LAMBERT
. I am a shoe-maker, and live at Edmonton. Camp came to me on the 7th of February - I told him where the two Berrys lived; I have seen this hat which was found in the barn; it is
William Berry
's hat; I have often seen him wear it, and John Berry also - I went with Camp to the barn and saw some footsteps in a track, which corresponded with the shoes of William and
John Berry
- I measured the width of them; I have compared them with this shoe, which William Berry had on - here is a hob on one side of their shoes, which had made a mark in the footsteps - I had sold them the shoes; I know they are theirs.

JOHN CAMP
. I am a constable. I went with Mr. Boards to Taylor and Catling's - I have been a farmer, and in my judgment the wheat found corresponds with the bulk - I know that Lambert got the shoes from Berry; when I took the Berrys, they said they were at home by nine o'clock, and then they said it was nothing to me - there is a communication from Catling's house to Taylor's, by a trap-door; here is the hat which was found in the barn.

Cross-examined. Q. Are they not both under the same roof? A. Yes, it is not common for houses of that description to have a communication - I never saw it before; the partition-wall is usually carried up to the top; the door is in the partition and pulls up - it is in the up stairs room; you go under the roof which hangs over, in a sloping way - the wheat found at Catling's, has some chaff in it now - Catling and Taylor were not at home when I went; Catling gave himself up the next morning.

THOMAS GILES
. I went with Camp; what he has stated is correct.

William Berry
's Defence. When the constable came to me, he asked where my hat was, and I showed him the one I have now in my hand; it is the one I have always worn when I have carried a fish basket; but I have, for the last three weeks, been working on the road; Lambert is my brother-in-law - he rushed into my house three months before and cut my neck with a knife; he has used my sister very ill - he has said he would do me an injury, and hang me if he could.

John Berry
's Defence. I never saw that hat in my life - I know nothing about it.
Taylor's Defence. The wheat found in my house was only a bushel and a half.
Catling's Defence. The wheat found at my house 'I had from my sister Hannah Fuller, and I thought it would be more good to me when my wife was confined than before.

HANNAH FULLER
. I am Catling's sister. His wife, my brother, and I, gleaned some wheat, and Catling had it about a week before from my house in Silver-street.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When did you glean it? A. In August last, about Edmonton - we gleaned sometimes in three or four fields in a day; this was mixed wheat - we gleaned some of Mr. Boards' and some of Mr. Knight's.

COURT. Q. Did you permit the small wheat to remain with it? A. We cleaned it ourselves in a little sieve on a sheet - I put the chaff on a little piece of ground before my garden; I know my sister had two chaff pillows given to her.
JURY to MR. BOARDS. Q. Did the chaff you found buried appear to be fresh buried? A. It was not matted as chaff usually is, which has been in a pillow or a bed.

W. BERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 33.

J. BERRY -
GUILTY . Aged 32.

TAYLOR -
GUILTY . Aged 32.

CATLING -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

758.
MICHAEL HOPKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of January , 1 cap, value 3s. , the goods of
John William Willis
.

RICHARD CHIPPERFIELD
. I live with Mr.
John William Willis
, a hatter . I was in his glass-case cleaning his window on the 10th of January - I saw the prisoner step in, take a cap, and run off; I overtook him in Bowlyard, St. Giles' - he had parted with the cap in Charles-street - it has not been found.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

759.
GEORGE NASH
and
JAMES LAW
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Hawkins
, from his person .

THOMAS HAWKINS
. I was in the Strand
about six o'clock in the evening, on the 19th of January: I had a handkerchief in my pocket - I turned, and saw it on the pavement; the prisoners were in custody.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You did notsee them till they were in custody? A. No; they were then within a yard of me; there were other persons in the street - there was a female at some distance.

THOMAS TIPPER
. I am a Policeman. On Thursday, the 19th of January, I was in the Strand, and saw the two prisoners following the prosecutor - I saw Nash put his right hand into his pocket, draw the handkerchief out, and give it to Law - I secured them both; Law threw it down; there was another with them, who escaped.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known Nash before? A. I have seen him with others.
The prisoners received a good character.

NASH -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

LAW -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

760.
HENRY FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of January , 3 leather-skins, value 6s.; 17 trunk-plates, value 1s., and 1 lock and key, value 6d., the goods of
Thomas Maltwood
, his master .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS MALTWOOD
. I am a trunk-maker , and live in Oxford-street
- the prisoner was my apprentice ; he has served four years of his time -
Robert Barker
was a journeyman of mine formerly. He called on me, and gave me some information - he brought me three brown sheepskins, a lock, and seventeen iron trunk plates; it was on a Sunday morning that Barker brought them, and on the Tuesday morning the prisoner called me aside when I came up from breakfast - he began the conversation himself; he said, "I took three skins and the lock to Mr. Barker to make a trunk, for which I had an order, but I have not got the order, and I will fetch them;" I told him it was then too late, Barker had told me all about it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is it not the custom, if young men want skins for business, to take them without asking you? A. No, never - I know Mr. White; I have granted him the materials to make a trunk for a friend when he asked me, but my men never take skins without asking me - I had discharged Barker, not having employment for him.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Do you ever permit your apprentices to have any work of their own? A. No; I always strictly forbid it - I have kept Barker employed out of doors doing what I could send him.

ROBERT BARKER
. I am a trunk-maker - I did live at Mr. Maltwood's; I live in Greece-street. The prisoner came to me on Saturday, the 28th of January; he said he wanted a trunk for a friend, and asked if I would make it for him - he said I should find the wood work, and he would buy the rest of the materials; I said I would make it for about 16s. - he said he could not give more than 12s., as he was only to have 24s. for it; this was agreed upon, and on the Sunday morning I received the leather, the lock, and the plates from my landlord's two children - as soon as I received them I went to his master, and told him- on the Tuesday morning the prisoner came to me again, and said he had not got the order for the trunk, and asked me to let him have the lock and the plates back again - he did not ask for the skins then; I said, "Where did you get these skins from?" he said, "From Mr. Maltwood's"- I said, "You can't have them, for Mr. Maltwood has them;" he said, "It is all up then," and off he ran.

Cross-examined by Mr. LEE. Q. Are the children here who delivered these articles to you? A. No; I was discharged from Mr. Maltwood's house, but I work at home; I never knew of journeymen taking materials to make a trunk, if I have asked for any thing it was given to me.
JURY. Q. When did the prisoner ask you for the skins back? A. About nine o'clock on the Tuesday morning, and he told Mr. Maltwood about ten.
EDWARD BARKER. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 19

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

761.
WILLIAM QUINT
was
indicted for embezzlement .

ISAAC LEWIS
. I am a baker , and live in Church-street, Bethnal-green
. The prisoner had been my journeyman for about nine months; he took out bread and was to receive money, which he was to give an account of as soon as he came in.

SARAH ELLIS
. I took in bread from the prosecutor to sell again. I paid the prisoner on Saturday, 17s. 6d. - he did not give me any bill or receipt.

SOPHIA SARAH BOYCE
. I serve in Mr. Lewis' shop - the prisoner pays me the money when Mr. Lewis is not there; he did not pay me the money which he had from Mrs. Ellis.

GEORGE CADOGAN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.

ALICE REYNOLDS
. I deal with the prosecutor. I paid the prisoner one morning, when he brought the bread; I did not have any bill or book - I do not know whether I paid him any thing on the 14th of January; I know the last morning he came to my house I paid him for half a dozen loaves.
ISAAC LEWIS. He booked these as unpaid; he never paid it to me.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Three Months .

762.
JOSEPH BUTLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of January , 1 cloak, value 16s. , the goods of
William James Stevenson
.

ROBERT COUSINS
. I am shopman to Mr.
William James Stevenson
, of Ratcliff-highway
. This cloak was lost from his shop, but I did not see it taken; I heard Stop thief! called, went to the door, and missed it - I did not see the prisoner that night, but a few days after Brown gave me notice that he was at the window, and I took him- the cloak has not been found.

JOHN BROWN
. I live close by the prosecutor's shop. -I saw the prisoner about half-past seven o'clock on the night of the 19th of January; he walked up and down the door two or three times, he then went on the step, took the cloak, and ran up Cannon-street - I cried out Stop thief! and the alarm was given, but he made his escape - this was on Thursday, between seven and eight o'clock, and on the Tuesday after I saw him again looking in at the window; I went and told Mr. Cousins the man was outside the door, and he was taken: I know the prisoner was the man that took the cloak - it was dark, but he hadpassed me three or four times, and looked at me - I saw him for five minutes.
MR. COUSINS. Brown gave a very clear description of the prisoner the same night, and it exactly corresponded with his person.
Prisoner's Defence. He said at the office that he only knew me by my coat and hat, but, having two or three hearings, he spoke more confidently of me.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

763.
JOHN ARUNDELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 1 cart, value 3l. , the goods of
George Martin
.

GEORGE MARTIN. I am a sawyer . On the 3rd of February, about seven o'clock in the morning, I left a cart at the corner of New-street, Bishopsgate
; I chained it to a scaffold-pole about four that evening, and missed it the next morning, about nine o'clock; I afterwards found it in Wentworth-street, at Spooner's, who keeps a livery-yard- I know nothing of the prisoner; I got information, and went to the prisoner's house, in Widegate-alley - he is a sweep; I asked if he had not got a cart in Wentworth-street, and he said he had - I asked how he came by it; he said he bought it on the Saturday morning, about seven o'clock - the officer then took him to the watch-house; he did not say where he bought it.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. You found that he is a sweep? A. Yes, and I believe he keeps a donkey or two - he said he bought the cart of two men on Saturday morning; I am sure he did not say Sunday morning.
COURT. Q. Did he say who they were? A. No; he said he knew two men, and he was on bail a week to find them.

JOHN SPOONER
. I keep a yard. On Saturday, the 4th, I found this cart in my yard, which I had never seen before- I inquired about, but could not hear any thing of it - the prisoner afterwards came to me about it, and asked if I was not surprised at seeing that strange cart there; I said Yes - he said, "It belongs to me - I bought it this morning for 13s.;" I knew him, and was then satisfied.
Cross-examined. Q. What has been his character? A. An honest man.

THOMAS HALL
. I saw the cart from five to ten minutes after seven o'clock on Saturday morning.

WILLIAM LAW
. I went to the prisoner with the prosecutor - what he has stated is correct.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought it between seven and eight o'clock on Saturday morning - it was rather too large for me, and I took it to Mr. Spooner's.
NOT GUILTY .

764.
FREDERICK BRIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 trunk, value 2s. , the goods of
William Illman
.

THOMAS STANDOVER
. I live opposite Mr. Illman's, in Dean-street, Soho
. On the 16th of February I saw the prisoner and some others near the house - I saw the prisoner take a trunk - he put it under his arm, and ran away; Mr. Wheeler followed him - I know he is the boy.

JAMES WHEELER
. I was going out at the door, and Mr. Standover said the lad had run away with a trunk from Mr. Illman's - I went and took him with it.

JAMES LUFF
. I took the prisoner, and have the trunk.

WILLIAM ILLMAN
. This is my property, and was in one of my windows.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

765.
JOHN BLACKFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of February , 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the monies of
Robert Cox
.

The same evidence was given in this case as against
Thomas Speak
, (see page 316.)
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

766.
JOHN PARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of January , 1 truss of clover-hay, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Gardiner
.
The same evidence was given as on the former trial, (see page 246.)
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

767.
ELLEN BLYTH
and
CATHERINE BARRY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 bag, value 2d.; 4 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 3d. in copper, the property of
William Nitingale
, from his person .

WILLIAM NITINGALE. I live in Lisle-street, Leicester-square, and am an engraver . On the 12th of February I met the prisoners in Hanover-street, Long-acre
, about three o'clock in the morning; they wished me to go home with them - I refused, stating that I had no money; I then felt Blyth's hand draw my bag and money out of my pocket, as I was standing opposite the house of an acquaintance, considering whether I should wake him up to let me in; I thought Blyth gave the bag and money to Barry, but I did not see her do it - I had 4s. 6d. in silver, and 3d. in copper in it - I said if they did not give me my money, I would give them in charge; two Policemen were coming by, and they took the money up from the ground - both the prisoners said they had not got it; I am sure it was Blyth's hand which took it from me.
Blyth. Q. Did you not meet me in Hanover-street? A. I was standing there, and you came up to me - I was not so sober as I am now - I did not say I had a small trifle, and give her the money.

JOHN BENNETT
. I am a Policeman. I was in Belton-street, and heard Blyth abusing the prosecutor, and using very bad language - I was going up to remove them for being disorderly, and when I got near, the prosecutor called Police - I went up, and seized Barry; she threw from her hand a purse, enclosed in this handkerchief, which she afterwards denied being hers - I said, "This is the woman that had the purse," and the prosecutor, whom I did not consider at all tipsy said, "This one (meaning Blyth) took it from me" - I took both the prisoners to the station, and found on them 4s. 6d. in silver, and 3d. in copper.

Blyth. I threw it down myself. Witness. No, Barry threw it down - Blyth was tipsy, and said she took it; she used the grossest language that ever I heard come from a woman - the prisoners are old acquaintances, and lived in the same street, in St. Giles'.

Blyth. He gave me the money to go home with him, and then he called the Policeman - Barry came up by accident, hearing the piece of work, and asked what was the matter - he said he was robbed, and I threw themoney down - I never saw Barry before that night - the prosecutor was very much in liquor.
Barry's Defence. I met the prisoner and the prosecutor in Hanover-street - I stood to see what was the matter, and the Policeman came and said that I dropped the purse, which I never had in my hand.

JOHN BENNETT
. I am quite sure Barry dropped the purse from her left hand.

WILLIAM NITINGALE
. They were both together when they first spoke to me - I did not see what Barry did with the purse.

BLYTH -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

BARRY -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

768.
THOMAS CATTLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 3 deal boards, value 8s. , the goods of
John Kewer
.

GEORGE MILLION. I am a Police-officer. On the morning of Wednesday, the 8th of February, I stopped the prisoner in Wilderness-row, carrying three deal boards; I asked where he got them - he said of Mr. King, in Henry-street, Back-road, Islington, one hour before; I took him to Bunhill-row station - I went to look for Mr. King, and no such person lived there.

Prisoner. I told him I had them of a Mr. King - he locked me in the station, and was not gone more than three quarters of an hour, and then he said he could not find him. Witness. I went to a Mr. King - he looked at the boards, and said they were not his; on the Friday I found Mr. Kewer, and he owned them.

JOHN KEWER
. I am a builder , and live in St. John-street-road. The boards are mine; I had not sold them- I had seen them safe in the morning of the 7th of February, before a house of mine in Sackville-street
, about three hundred yards from where the prisoner was stopped by the officer.

Prisoner. Q. How can you swear to plain deal boards? A. They have been planed for a length of time, turned upside down, and used for scaffolding - I lost twelve of them from the same stack, and five on the Wednesday evening; they are the same length as mine, and have some cement on them - I have not a doubt of them.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought them of a young man named King for 8s. - I went up the Back-road, Islington, and we had some gin; I parted with him, and then, in mistake, I went straight on, instead of turning - when I got to St. John-square the officer stopped me.
GUILTY. Aged 26.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Two Months .

769.
CATHERINE COLVIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 1 jacket, value 15s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 5s., and 1 necklace, value 10s. , the goods of
James McKelvey
.

JAMES McKELVEY
. I am a seaman , and live in Park-street, Limehouse. On the 8th of February I came from a voyage - I went to lodge at the prisoner's house, in the Match-walk
; I took there two chests, a hammock, and two parrots in a cage, which I had from Sierra Leone - the next morning I went out with the prisoner's husband to look for my wife, leaving the prisoner at home; I returned to the prisoner's house on the Thursday morning I then missed my jacket, trousers, beads, and five rupees and a half in money, which I had given her to take care of for me, and one parrot, which she had sold for 25s.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long were you at her house? A. About eight hours; I slept there, up stairs, with one of the women - some of the women seemed to be indifferent characters; I did not make the prisoner a present of one of the parrots - the prisoner did not lend me 1s. - I did not make her any present.

THOMAS SIZER
. I am in the employ of Mr. Kennedy, a pawnbroker, at Shadwell. On the 8th of February the prisoner came to the shop, and I bought four rupees and a half of her; I asked whose they were - she said her husband's, who had lately come home from the South Seas, where he had been for five years; the next morning she brought this cornelian necklace - I lent her 4s. on it.

PETER PETERSON KURBO
. I lodge next door to the prisoner. On the 8th of February she gave me a pair of trousers, and told me to go and get 2s. on them, to provide breakfast for a lodger of her's - I pawned them in Charles-street for 3s.; I gave her the money and the duplicate.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you been in the house? A. Not after the prosecutor was - I go on errands for one and another.

JOHN JOHNSON
. I am in the employ of a pawnbroker. I took in these trousers on the 8th of February, from Kurbo.

WILLIAM WHEELER
. I am an officer. On the 9th of February I received this parrot from one Crickaley - I then took the prisoner, but found nothing on her; I asked what she had done with the rupees - she said she had spent them at different public-houses for gin, and she knew nothing about the waistcoat and trousers.

JAMES McKELVEY
. These trousers and necklace are mine - the jacket has not been found; I gave no one permission to make any use of them.
Prisoner's Defence. I have witnesses who were there when he gave them to me.

ANN BATH
. I live at No. 2, in the Match-walk; my husband is in Greenwich-college. I saw the prosecutor in the prisoner's place about a fortnight ago; I saw him give her a parrot, some rupees, and some beads - he was very much intoxicated, and he told her that whatever she wished to have she might have, and that on the day he was paid, he would make her a handsome present; she was quite sober - she thanked him for what he gave her; he had two parrots, and I think this is the one he gave her.

COURT. Q. Did you see him make her a present of his trousers? A. No - his two boxes were brought in, but they were not locked; he did not tell her to take care of the parrot and the rupees - he gave them to her; I was not surprised at it, a gift is a gift - there was another person present; it was between seven and eight o'clock in the evening - her husband was not there at the time.

MARY PETERSON
. My husband is a butcher, and lives in Middlesex-street, Whitechapel. I was at the prisoner's house this night fortnight, I think it was - I went to inquire for a Mrs. Folger, to wash for me; the prisonerasked me to sit down - the prosecutor and her husband came in together about eight o'clock; the prosecutor sat down on a chair, and said, "Who is the mistress of this house?" the prisoner said she was - the prosecutor then gave her some beads, and some silver pieces; he said he had two birds, and he would give her one and keep the other; I did not see the birds while I was there.

COURT. Q. Did not he tell her to take care of the beads and the silver pieces for him? A. No, Sir, he gave them to her when she said she was the mistress; he said,"Here is something I have got the give you," and he pulled them out and gave them to her - they were silver foreign money, and I think the beads were red, but I was in a hurry to get home.

WILLIAM WHEELER
. Here are some papers which I received from Mrs. Bath; she went by the name of Collins then - she said she had them of the prisoner; the prosecutor says they must have been taken out of his chest.

JAMES McKELVEY. I gave the prisoner the rupees to take care of for me, but the beads and the papers were taken from my chest - I brought the parrots for my two children; I paid 13s. 2d. for my lodging at the prisoner's that night, and I have the receipt in my pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the trousers and jacket - he gave me the necklace and the rupees.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Seven Years .

770.
HONORA CASEY
was
indicted for embezzlement .

REUBEN SMITH
. I am a milkman , and live in Smart's-buildings, St. Giles' - the prisoner was a milk carrier in my service, for seventeen or eighteen months. It was her duty to receive money from customers.

MARY ROBINS
. I am servant to Mr. Fowler, in Newman-street
. On the 21st of January I paid the prisoner 8s. 10 1/2d. for milk, supplied by Mr. Smith - Mr. Smith's name was to the bill, but we do not keep the bills.

EMMA MAISEY
. I am servant to Mr. Sanders, of Mornington-place. On the 23rd of January I paid the prisoner 2s. 4d., on Mr. Smith's account - I did not have a bill.

MARY AYRES
. I am in the service of Mr. Hendry, of Oxford-street. I paid the prisoner 1s. 8d. on the 26th of January, which I had received from my master to be paid to Mr. Smith for milk.

REUBEN SMITH
. The prisoner ought to have accounted to me for the money every day when she came home - she used to bring home some coppers every day, but she has not lately paid me any bill: I believe she cannot read or write - she has received Mr. Saunders' bills for sixteen weeks and Mr. Hendry's for twenty - I asked her about Mr. Hendry's, and she said he was out of town; I was always at home, as I had been ill for some time - I used to see her every afternoon, and when I asked if these persons had paid, she said they had not; she had 9s. a week and her breakfast.
GUILTY. Aged 22

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 3 Weeks .

771.
THOMAS DUTFIELD
was
indicted for embezzlement .

ANN HUDSON. I am the wife of
William Hudson
, who lives in Kingsland-road
, and is a butcher - the prisoner was in his service for about four months; he boarded in the house, and received weekly wages. One Thursday, I think on the 9th of February, as I was sitting in the shop, he applied to me to make out Mrs. Daniels' receipt, and said she would pay the money on Friday or Saturday morning- I gave him the receipt for 2l. 19s. 3d. - he never gave me the money; he was at home till the Saturday afternoon, and then he left us - he was taken on the Sunday morning; I asked him if he remembered that I gave him the receipt for Mrs. Daniels - he said Yes: I said, "You have not given me the money;" he said, "I know I received it, but have not given it to you;" we have heard that he is married.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Did he account with you or your husband? A. With me, always; I am sure he asked me for the receipt on Thursday night, and on the Sunday the Police-officer brought him to our house - I cannot swear that money he has received on a Monday has not been paid to me till the Thursday or Friday, but it ought not to be so; he behaved very well before this.

CHARLOTTE TAPLING
. I am the wife of
George Tapling
; he keeps the Acton Arms. On Friday, the 10th of January, the prisoner called on me for orders - I ordered a shoulder of veal, which he brought me - it came to 6s. 9d., and I paid him in two half-crowns, one shilling, and a sixpence; he owed me 3d.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you any memorandum of this? A. No; there was a small ticket with the meat, but I have mislaid it.

ELIZABETH RICHARDS
. I am in the service of Mrs. Daniels, of Kingsland; I paid the prisoner 2l. 19s. 3d. on the Friday - I gave him three sovereigns, and he brought 9d. change; the officer has the bill and receipt.
MRS. HUDSON. This is the bill and receipt he had of me; I asked him on Saturday morning if Mrs. Tapling had paid him, and he said No.
Cross-examined. Q. Has he many customers to go to? A. Yes; he was to bring in the money, if any body thought proper to pay him.

RICHARD HAWKES
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner to Mrs. Hudson; she told him he had not given her the money from Mrs. Daniels - he said he had received it, but had not given it to her.
GUILTY. Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

772.
HARRIET DAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February , 1 blanket, value 3s. , the goods of
Joseph Wise
.

MARY WISE
. I am the wife of
Joseph Wise
; he is a carpenter , and lives in New-road, Chelsea
. The prisoner and a foot soldier, who passed as her husband, hired a furnished room in our house; on a Saturday, the beginning of February, in consequence of some suspicion, I examined the bed, after she had been there a week, and missed a blanket - she said she had not had it, but I found the duplicate under the bed - on the Tuesday after they took the room the soldier was ordered to Kew.

JOHN GAMMON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have a blanket, pawned by the prisoner, on the 9th of February, for 2s.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I intended to get it out again when I got the money.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

737.
THOMAS DUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 1 counterpane, value 5s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 2 pillows, value 3s.; 2 blankets, value 6s.; 2 sheets, value 5s., and 2 flat-irons, value 1s. , the goods of
John Joice
.

SARAH JOICE. I am the wife of
John Joice
- we live in Little Windmill-street
, Golden-square. The prisoner occupied a back room in my husband's house - he was taken into custody on the 8th of February, on another charge; I then went into his room, and missed the articles stated.

WILLIAM GOULD
. I am apprentice to a pawnbroker. I have two blankets, pawned on the 6th of December, and two irons on the 17th of December, in the name of Thompson; I cannot say by whom, but these are the duplicates.

WILLIAM ORGER
. I am an officer. I found these duplicates on the prisoner's wife; the prisoner said he took the things, and pawned them, but he was in great distress, and meant to redeem them when he got employment.

THOMAS SHIRLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, pawned by the prisoner on the 9th of November, in the name of Thompson - this is the duplicate I gave him.

SARAH JOICE. These are my articles. The prisoner is a dyer - they had nothing of any value of their own; they might he in distress - he owes me a good deal for rent, besides what I have lent him; his wife could earn 12s. a week, but they did not make the best use of it.

Prisoner's Defence. I am a native of Liverpool, where I was in partnership in business, but through unforeseen circumstances have been brought to distress; a gentleman at Islington has promised to employ me.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Ten Days .

774.
JOHN DRANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 box, value 3d., and 2s. 5d. in copper monies, numbered , the property of
William Morrish
.
SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the property of some persons unknown.

ISAAC STEVENSON
. I am clerk of the boatmen's chapel, at Paddington
. On the 12th of February I saw the prisoner sitting by the fire, at the lower end of the chapel, when I went in; and while we were singing the first hymn he removed, and went near the door - he then went out; I thought something was not right - I followed, and asked how he came to leave the chapel; he said, "For God's sake, forgive me, I did it for want," and he gave me this charity-box, which had stood on the mantel-piece in the chapel - Mr. Morrish is the sub-treasurer , and any money missing he would be required to account for, but we did not know what was in it till it was opened, and 2s. 5d. was then found in it; it was not fixed.
NOT GUILTY .

775.
JOHN GATEHOUSE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of January , 1 wheelbarrow, value 10s. , the goods of
John Chapman
.

HANNAH CHAPMAN
. I am the wife of
John Chapman
. On the 25th of January my husband sent the prisoner with this wheelbarrow, to fetch a tub from a gentleman's house - he went away, and did not return; he had been a week in our service.

JOHN ROLSTON
. I apprehended the prisoner as I was returning from Clerkenwell, on Monday week; I took him by the arm, and said, "Do you hear what Mrs. Chapman charges you with?" he said, "I don't deny taking it;" he said he had sold it to a man for 5s. or 6s. - that he could not tell the man's name, nor where he lived, but it was in the straight road from Hammersmith to Brentford; I went with him, and got it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .

776.
FREDERICK GODDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of February , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
William Holdsworth
, from his person .

WILLIAM HOLDSWOTH. I live at Kingsland-green, and am a butcher . On the 19th of February I was in Shoreditch
; I met four boy s - I rather suspected them, felt my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; I saw the prisoner crossing the road - I ran, and took him; he took my handkerchief from his pocket, and threw it down in the road; I took him to the station - this is my handkerchief.
TIMOTHY RYAN. I am a Police-officer. I received the prisoner in charge.
GUILTY. Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.

777.
WILLIAM CORNSEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of February , 1 cap, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Cambridge Smith
, from his person .

THOMAS CAMBRIDGE SMITH
. I am the son of
Ann Smith
- she lives in North-street, Spitalfields. On Saturday, the 4th of February, I was in the Tenter-ground
, playing; the prisoner came behind me, and took my cap; I saw him run away with it - I ran to my mother, and spoke to the Policeman, who took him.

JOHN SMITH
. I was with my brother in the Tenterground - I saw the prisoner snatch the cap off his head, and run away; I saw him afterwards with the Policeman.

JOHN REYNOLDS
. I saw the prisoner take the cap off Smith's head.

HENRY BOLTON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner in Spitalfields-market on the 15th, four or five hundred yards from the Tenter-ground; he was pointed out to me by Thomas Cambridge Smith - I did not find the cap.
NOT GUILTY .

778.
DANIEL HOBBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of February , 2 flat-irons, value 18d., the goods of
Jane Thompson
, from the person of
William Thompson
.

WILLIAM THOMPSON
. I am nine years and three months old, and live with my mother. I was carrying these iron to the opposite side of the way, in Waterloo-street, St. Luke's
- the prisoner came, snatched them out of my hand, and ran away; they belong to a neighbour, but my mother was answerable for them.

CHARLES WORLEY
