. I am a pawnbroker, in the employ of Mr. Cottle, of Old-street. The prisoner pawned these flat-irons with me.
JANE THOMPSON. These are the irons - I delivered them to my son to take home; I was answerable for them.

JOHN FOY
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner.

GUILTY. Aged 12. -
Judgment Respited
.

779.
DAVID JOHN HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 cap, value 4s., the goods of
Benjamin King
, from the person of
George King
.

GEORGE KING
. I am ten years old. I know the prisoner - I was in Bell-street
, near the Key public-house, and saw the prisoner - he came behind me, took my cap off my head, and ran away; I live in Bury-place, with my father - we sell milk; the prisoner put my cap under his coat, and ran off with it - I gave an alarm, and he was pursued.

THOMAS OLDACRE
. I am butcher. I heard the alarm of Stop thief! I went into Chapple-street - I saw several persons running; the prisoner was stopped at the corner of Market-street, and I took the cap from under his coat -I am a constable of the parish; I saw the lad crying, and he said the prisoner had taken his cap - the prisoner asked me to let him go, and said he did not take it.
Prisoner's Defence. The cap was taken off his head, and thrown to me - I took it up, and ran off with it.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

780.
JOSEPH HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of February , 1 pig-trough, value 2s. , the goods of
John Woodcock
.

PHILIP JONES. I am a Policeman. I was on duty on the 12th of February, near the Three Colts, Grove-street, Hackney - I saw the prisoner with a pig-trough under his arm; I asked where he got it - he said he bought it of a baker, for 2s., on the Saturday night - I said I was not altogether satisfied; and in taking him to the station, he said it was of no use telling me lies, that he found it in the field.

JOHN WOODCOCK
. I live in Wick-lane, Hackney
, and am a market-gardener . This trough is mine; I can swear to it by the two ends - I had seen it safe about five o'clock on the Saturday evening, and it was taken before seven the next morning - the prisoner was taken about one hundred and fifty yards from my house.
Prisoner's Defence. I honestly picked it up in the field, about half-past six o'clock in the morning - it was laying down by a bit of cow dung.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 22.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

781.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of February , 1 glass goblet, value 1s., and 2 wineglasses, value 1s. , the goods of
James Soane
.

BENJAMIN WILLMERE
. I live with
James Soane
, a chinaman , in Oxford-street
- these glasses were in a basket, outside the door; the prisoner was brought into the shop in the evening; I saw them found on him - I knew them to be master's.

GEORGE STRATTON
. I am a butcher, and live next door to Soane. I saw the prisoner take a glass from the basket, and walk away - I followed, and gave him in charge, I saw two wine glasses and a goblet found on him.

JOSIAH EVANS
. I am a Policeman. I found the glasses in the prisoner's hat.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Seven Days .

782.
ALFRED WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of February , 1 dead fowl, value 2s. , the goods of
George Brooks
.

MARTHA BROOKS
. I am the wife of
George Brooks
, a poulterer , of Hill-street, Clapton
. On the 16th of February, about seven o'clock, I missed three fowls from the shop-window; Williams brought the prisoner to the shop, with a fowl, which I am certain of - I had plucked it, and noticed it particularly.

HENRY WILLIAMS
. I am a Policeman. About twenty minutes past seven o'clock in the evening, I took the prisoner in Kingsland, with another man - the prisoner had a fowl under his jacket; he said he had bought it of a countryman, at Tottenham, for 1s. - his companion made off; I took the fowl to Brooks' next morning, and she claimed it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

783.
SARAH JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 1 purse, value 2d., and 4 sovereigns, the property of
George Arundel
, from his person .

GEORGE ARUNDEL. I live at Chelsea, and am not in business . On Friday night last, about eleven o'clock, I was in Drury-lane
, with Mr. Pinnel, and saw the prisoner; I think she spoke to me first - we went into a public-house, in Drury-lane with her; I think it is the White Horse - two girls went into the house, but she was alone; I was sober - I had been dining with a friend; we staid there a very few minutes - she sat next to me; we had something to drink - Pinnel paid for it; I then observed on the seat a paper or two, which had come from my pocket - I felt, and my purse was gone; I am quite sure it was safe when I went to the house - the other girls sat on the other side of me - we were in front of the bar; I told Pinnel I had lost my purse, and suspected the prisoner; he took hold of her hand - I went out for an officer, but before I returned they had got one; I found my purse in the officer's hands.

Cross-examined by MR. WALESBY. Q. Where had you dined? A. With a friend, near Clerkenwell - I recollect seeing a band of musicians in Red Lion-passage; I stood listening to them - I am fond of music, and very likely asked them to play particular tunes; I did not ask them to follow me into Holborn - I did not dance to the tunes; I will not swear I did not beat time with my foot - I am generally merry; I did not caper nor dance - I saw the prisoner there, and she remained in our company all the way to Drury-lane; there were two other women with the music, who, I believe, were in our company before I saw the prisoner - we met them in Red Lion-passage; we all five went into a public-house in Drury-lane - I do not know what I drank there; I do not think the prisoner was affected with liquor - certainly not so as not to know what she said or did - I told the officer there were six or seven sovereigns in my purse; I made a mistake, there were but four - I recollected having paid away two and changed one.

RICHARD PINNEL
. I live in Long-acre, with my mother - I am out of business. Mr. Arundel and I dined together, between two and three o'clock, and left thehouse about six or seven; we went to Clerkenwell after dinner - we had dined at the York Arms, Shirelane, which I kept two years ago; it is not frequented by bad women, particularly - Mr. Arundel then went to call on a friend of his in Clerkenwell; I waited while he went in - we returned through Red Lion-square, met two or three women there round the music, and took two or three of them into Holborn, to a house kept by Mr. Thomas, stopped there about a quarter of an hour and drank- it is a wine-vaults; we then went to a wine-vaults in Drury-lane with the three women; the prisoner was one of them - they had followed us; Mr. Arundel missed his purse - I held the prisoner's hands, and he went for an officer; the prisoner then told me if I would let her go she would give me the purse, and gave it me from her bosom- it contained four sovereigns.

Cross-examined. Q. You dined at the York Arms? A. Yes - we had wine for dinner; we got to Red Lion-square between eight and nine o'clock - we had stopped at a public-house on the way; I recollect the music in Red Lion-passage - I did not dance, nor did he; Mr. Arundel might move round with a lady - there were several women about, and two ladies were talking to us; the prisoner was there - we all five went into Holborn; I had some sherry and bitters - we treated the girls with what they chose; the prisoner was not intoxicated - I do not think I drank there; I swear the prisoner was not intoxicated; I was perfectly sober - how the purse got into her bosom - I cannot tell.

GEORGE CONNER
. I am pot-boy at the White Lion, Drury-lane - I saw the prisoner there with two more bad girls - I saw her take the purse out of her bosom, and give it to Pinnel; she was tipsy, but not insensible.
Cross-examined. Q. Was Arundel rather tipsy? A. No, he was cheerful.

HENRY BURBIDGE
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge; Pinnel handed me the purse with four sovereigns in it - the prisoner said she was drunk, and was not aware of having put it into her bosom.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you notice whether she was tipsy? A. She appeared rather so; she fainted away two or three times.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in Red Lion-square - the gentleman came to me; the music was playing - he asked me to go and have a glass with him; we went to Holborn- he asked the music to follow; I went into a gin-shop with him, and got very much intoxicated.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 22.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

784.
GEORGE PARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 1 carriage-strap, value 2s. , the goods of
John Trotter
.

WILLIAM BURNABY
. I am footman to
John Trotter
, Esq ., of Park-place, Edgware-road. This strap was taken from the hind part of the carriage, as it was going down Oxford-street
, from Covent-garden, at half-past eleven o'clock on the night of the 17th of February; I was inside, and saw the prisoner come from the pavement, get on the step, and take it; I stopped the coach, got out, and took the prisoner with it on the spot: I got into the carriage on purpose, as we had lost so many straps.

JOSEPH STANNAND
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner, and have the strap, which I took out of his waistcoat pocket - it is the check brace.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

785.
PETER PERKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of February , 1 silk gown, value 9s., and 2 suits of boy's clothes , the goods of
John Garrard
.

JOHN GARRARD
. I live in Hackney-road
, and am a clothes salesman . On the 6th of February, about eight o'clock in the morning, I was opening my shop, and taking the shutters backwards; I was asked by a woman if I had lost any thing - I looked, and said I had: she said a man had come out with something, which appeared to be a silk gown and some boys' clothes, and gone down the next turning; I went, but could not see him.

ESTHER GILHAM
. I was coming across the road, and saw a man come out of the shop, with a bundle; he looked round, and the prisoner came out after him - they hurried down Austin-street; the prisoner is one of them - I described him to Vann, and he took him.

THOMAS VANN
. I took the prisoner from Gilham's description.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

786.
JAMES PHELPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March, 1831 , 3 bushels of wheat, value 30s. , the goods of
George Corfe
.

WILLIAM BARRETT
. I am an officer of Isleworth and Twickenham. On the 22nd of March, 1831, about two o'clock in the morning, I fell in with the prisoner and another, near Sir
Benjamin Hobhouse
's gate, three or four hundred yards from the prosecutor's - it was in the high road to London; the prisoner was first - I laid hold of him, and I saw behind him a man carrying a sack - I put the prisoner aside, and seized the sack; the man who had it struggled with me, and we both went down, but I still held the sack; the prisoner begged me to let it pass - I said they might go for that time, but I would retain the property; they went on - a great deal of the wheat came out of the sack; I took it, as well as I could, to the prosecutor's - the next morning I went to the barn; I saw a little track of wheat from there to the high road, and on to the place where I met the men, where it had come out in a body; I compared it with what was in the barn, it corresponded - the other man has since been transported for another robbery - I did not find the prisoner till last Wednesday night; I knew him before - he had lived in the neighbourhood twelve months.
Prisoner. Q. Can you say I was near the man? A. Yes, you was close to him; I told you I would bring you to justice, but you might go that time.

JOSEPH FULLER
. I am a labourer in the service of Mr. Corfe; his barn was locked up, and all was right - I went the next morning at six o'clock, and found the lock had been removed, and somebody had been in the barn - I missed about three bushels of wheat - the sack was not my master's; there was a track of wheat from the barn to the main road - I had threshed the wheat; I have been all my life acquainted with wheat - I have no doubt it was Mr. Corfe's.
GEORGE CORFE. I am a farmer . This wheat was taken from my barn - I compared it with what was left, and have no doubt it was mine; the prisoner had worked for me, and knew my premises.

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the wheat - I had been watching Mr. Corfe's premises when he had expected to be set on fire; I heard a piece of work that night - I went back, and saw Young and Barrett struggling; Barrett said, "Young, you may go, and if I had known you had been this road I would have gone some other;" I gave Barrett a lift up with the wheat.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Seven Years .

787.
THOMAS WEBSTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 copper builer, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Wood
, and fixed to a building of his .

WILLIAM CLARK
. I am an officer. On the 13th of February, about a quarter before seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner past my house in Clerkenwell
, about ten minutes' walk from the building where this copper was taken from - he went into a rag-shop, just below where I lived, to sell it; he came out in two or three minutes, and told another boy it was all right - he went back, and went into the shop again; I took the other boy, and sent a Policeman, who took the prisoner; the other boy was discharged.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a Policeman. I went and took the prisoner coming out the second time, with the copper in his hand.

HENRY WOOD
. I live at Shepherd's-bush - this copper was in a building belonging to me; I have seen it fitted, and it fits exactly - I have not seen the premises this eighteen months; it is my house, and the tenants have left it.

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

788.
RICHARD JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of February , 2 shirts, value 6s. , the goods of
William Moore
.

TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating them to belong to
William Atkinson
and
Henry Holtzenyer
.

SARAH MOORE
. I am the wife of
William Moore
, and am a washer-woman - we live at Tottenham
. I had these shirts on the common to dry; one of them belongs to Henry Holtzenyer, and the other to
William Atkinson
-I was not at home when they were taken.

JAMES LANBOURN
. I am a gardener, at Tottenham. On the 15th of February, between one and two o'clock, I saw the prisoner running away with the property concealed in his apron; he might be three hundred yards from the prosecutor's house - I went and took him with the shirts; there were two other persons; we took them all, but the other two were discharged; one of them had been watching near the dung-hill, and he struck me on my arm.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Did you tell the same story before the Grand Jury as you have here? A. Yes; they threw out the bill against Dison and Humphries - I am gardener to Mr. James Roe.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The things were laying in the road, and I took them up and put them in my apron.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

789.
GEORGE WELLBANK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 10 yards of printed cotton, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Belton
.

EDWARD BELTON. I keep a draper's shop in Lisson-grove
. On the 8th of February, about half-past four o'clock, I was at home, but did not see this cotton taken.

MICHAEL JOHNSON
. I live next door to the prosecutor; I saw the prisoner and another boy for some time opposite my window; I watched them, and saw them run; I then went out; the prisoner had got the printed cotton, and dropped it on my rails; I suspected he had stolen it - I took it up, and he was pursued and taken; the other. boy got away; I am quite sure the prisoner is the person who was running with the cotton and dropped it; he only ran into the next street.

THOMAS FURSEY
. I am an officer. I have the property. (Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence (written.) I passed the shop of the prosecutor; whilst doing so, a boy, who had taken a piece of print, threw it on the ground and ran away; a person from the shop ran after him, and I picked up the print, intending to keep it until the person who had gone in pursuit of the thief returned.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

790.
PETER WALES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of January , 2lbs. of mutton, value 1s. 5d., and 3 lbs. of beef, value 1s. 6d. , the property of
Henry Rogers
.

WILLIAM ROGERS
. I am brother to Henry Rogers, a butcher . On the 12th of January, in the evening, I was serving in the shop, and missed some meat off the board, but did not see it taken; the prisoner was taken by the Policeman, who brought the meat back to the shop; he had got half a mile; he had not bought any thing.

THOMAS KELLY
. I am a Policeman. On the 12th of January I was in Brick-lane, Old-street; I saw the prisoner and another boy ; the prisoner had a basket - I followed them to Golden-lane, and took the basket from the prisoner; I saw two joints of meat in it - I said,"Where did you get this?" he said a boy gave it him; the other boy ran away - I inquired, and found the prosecutor.

WILLIAM ROGERS
. I can swear to the meat, by the score of the mutton, and the beef I had cut myself - it was between seven and eight o'clock in the evening.

GUILTY. Aged 16. -
Judgment Respited
.

791.
JAMES WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of February , 1 carpet, value 10s. , the goods of
Mary Price
.

MARY PRICE
. I live in Union-walk, Union-street, Kingsland-road
; the prisoner lodged eight months with me, and was a shoe-maker ; I keep a small clothes-shop . On the 10th of February I missed a piece of carpet - he was not at home then, but came home at night; I sent for an officer, and charged him with taking it - he denied all knowledge of it, but in going to the station he told me it was at the pawnbroker's.

WILLIAM EVETT
. I am a pawnbroker I took in this carpet from the prisoner.
-. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner; he told us where the carpet was, and said he had taken it. (Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. It was my intention to have redeemed the carpet, or I should have absconded.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .
The number of Prisoners committed for Trial at the present Session, was 395 Of whom were Acquitted or discharged by Proclamation.....131 Convicted.....264 Of whom 9 have Received Sentence of Death.
11..... Transportation for Life.
143 carried up.
143 brought up.
103 have been Imprisoned for various terms, Whipped or Fined, 18 Judgments Respited.
